text: Jennifer Fedorink does with Creamo containers what Brian Jungen did with Air Jordans or Andy Warhol with  Campbell Soup cans: makes them into something totally unexpected. Thousands of empty Creamo containers are bundled into bags, looking like nothing so much as hard-edged marshmallows. Other media Fedorink works with include recycled baking parchment and assemblages that suggest the anarchic hippie works of bill bissett or Al Neil.

text:
A great deal of ingenuity goes into such work.
"We often end up using what other people throw out in our miniatures," says Shiells. "Corrugated cardboard makes for great house siding. Creamo containers become lampshades and acorn caps can be used for salad bowls."

text:
The butter police had swept the place before we got there. So had the creamo patrol. But no one had checked the in-room mini-bar where a jar of cashews was waiting to seduce us.
My friend and I -- starved by a day too busy for lunch -- gobbled the cashews before heading down for our Westin Bayshore Spa Escape introductory dinner. Spa food, we figured, would be spartan. Better load up a bit first, right?

text: The milk wagon -- a horse drawn cart -- came by the house daily and you could hear the clop-clop long before it arrived at your door. Mother would say, "go and get one bottle of milk and one of creamo" and I would run out. The milkman got down from the cart and took the milk out the back -- the horse only slowed but never stopped.

text: But unfortunately, no one seems quite sure what a 'francophone' is.  According to the Treasury Board, a 'francophone' is a person whose mother tongue is French, presumably a French Canadian in most cases; thus, in a statement to the House of Commons in March, 1971, Drury was able to announce a policy of â??accelerated recruitment of francophones to the public serviceâ?�. (The passionate uproar that followed a discovery of a â??secretâ?� document purporting of hire 250 Quebec students indicates how popular this policy was in English Ottawa!) However, the Public Service Commission, responsible for all actual recruiting for the service, is forbidden by law to hire on racial grounds.  So <u>their</u> definition of a â??francophoneâ?� is, any person who can â??work creatively inFrenchâ?�.  When is an anglophone a francophone?  Where is a francophone an anglophone?  What is Jean Dupont, a hypothetical Ontarian, who grew up with both languages or perhaps with English only?  Or Michel X, whose personal language is French, but, after long years of exposure, prefers to work in English? â?¦

text: You may wonder what 'anglophones' and 'francophones' are. These terms refer respectively to those whose mother tongue is English, and those whose mother tongue is French. Mother tongue is the language first learned in childhood and still understood. You may be neither and belong to one of the many ethnic groups that enrich our Canadian society.  In this case, for statistical purposes only, you will be included with either group depending on the language in which you are more proficient in communicating with others, i.e., your primary language.
clippedText: You may wonder what 'anglophones' and 'francophones' are. These terms refer respectively to those whose mother tongue is English, and those whose mother tongue is French. text: BATHURST --  Although New Brunswick is an officially bilingual province -- the only one in Canada -- there are growing doubts among Acadians that it is possible to build a society that protects the rights and culture of two linguistic groups. Last year, Acadians fought anglophones in the streets of Bathurst, and the battle was over language rights. The city's French majority wanted its own unilingual school administration.

shortMeaning: speaking neither English nor French as a mother tongue
text: This trend, combined with an immigration policy which, since 1985, has contributed to a gradual increase in immigration (MCCI, 1990a), has made multi-ethnicity a major trait of the Montreal school system. In 1990-91, four school boards on the island reported that 35% of their student population was Allophone (speaking neither French or English), and almost half of the schools on the Island of Montreal reported an Allophone population of over 25%. It can now be said, and with a fair degree of certainty, that Bill 101 has achieved its overt aim: earlier enrollment trends have been reversed and minority students are increasingly enrolled in French, rather than English, language schools. At the present time, seventy percent of the Allophone student population, and more than 90% of the children of newly arrived immigrants attend French schools, as compared to 11% at the beginning of the 1970s (CSIM, 1991). Furthermore, recently observed trends suggest that factors other than the coercitive measures of Bill 101 are contributing to attendance in French language schools. For example, an important number of Anglophone and Allophone children, who have a legal right to English language schooling, have voluntarily chosen to attend French language schools (8516 in 1993).(f.4) Similarly, in 1986, more than 83% of Allophones graduating from French high schools chose to continue their education in French post-secondary institutions (CLF, 1991).
clippedText: In 1990-91, four school boards on the island reported that 35% of their student population was Allophone (speaking neither French or English), and almost half of the schools on the Island of Montreal reported an Allophone population of over 25%. It can now be said, and with a fair degree of certainty, that Bill 101 has achieved its overt aim: earlier enrollment trends have been reversed and minority students are increasingly enrolled in French, rather than English, language schools.

shortMeaning: someone whose first language is neither English nor French
text:
Children acting as family interpreters are increasingly common in Canada, experts say, with young people enlisted to help their parents or other relatives with everything from conversations and shopping trips to apartment leases or doctors' orders. There are no statistics available on how many children and teens take on this role, but one in five people in Canada is an allophone -- someone whose first language is neither French nor English -- and their ranks are growing.

There were 6.3 million allophones in 2006, according to the latest census data available -- an increase of nearly one million people, or 18 per cent, over 2001. Of the 1.1 million immigrants who arrived in Canada between 2001 and 2006, 80 per cent were allophones. Canadians report more than 200 mother tongues.
clippedText: Children acting as family interpreters are increasingly common in Canada, experts say, with young people enlisted to help their parents or other relatives with everything from conversations and shopping trips to apartment leases or doctors' orders. There are no statistics available on how many children and teens take on this role, but one in five people in Canada is an allophone -- someone whose first language is neither French nor English -- and their ranks are growing.

text: The proposal has attracted widespread criticism from Quebec Education Minister Claude Ryan, among others. Still, the commission's proposal addresses a demographic challenge that increasingly worries the province's francophone majority: how to integrate a swelling immigrant population -- 68 per cent of which does not speak French -- into the province's shrinking linguistic mainstream. Compounding the challenge is francophone Quebec's tumbling birth rate. It is a problem that the Parti Quebecois sought to address in its 1977 French Language Charter known as Bill 101, which required all nonanglophone immigrants -- and even some anglophones -- to attend French-language schools. But that measure has had an unintended result: many French schools are now dominated by nonfrancophone students, dubbed allophones.

shortMeaning: "those whose mother tongue is neither English nor French"
text: Unjust: Numerous provincial residents also say that their politicians' actions have been a reasonable response to what they perceive as unjust policies of the Quebec government. They frequently cite Quebec's December, 1988, ban on the use of languages other than French on outdoor commercial signs. Indeed, Filmon himself withdrew his support for the Meech Lake accord following the introduction of that law. "It is scary that laws like that now apply in Canada," said Arthur Gunn, who operates Winnipeg's famed Gunn's Bakery, which his parents, immigrants from Poland, founded in 1937. Gunn also criticized a proposal before the Montreal Catholic School Commission to ban "allophone" students -- those whose mother tongue is neither English nor French -- from speaking languages other than French on school property. He added, "When immigrant kids are forbidden to speak English in Montreal playgrounds, that is not a free Canada."
clippedText: Gunn also criticized a proposal before the Montreal Catholic School Commission to ban "allophone" students -- those whose mother tongue is neither English nor French -- from speaking languages other than French on school property. text:
Micro-filtered milk is processed according to a microfiltration process that eliminates bacteria, making it possible to pasteurize milk at a lower temperature. This process produces a creamier milk with a longer shelf life than traditional milk, anywhere from 10 days to several weeks.

text:
The author says that before Modern Coffee Creams were invented it was usual to use condensed milk. Nowadays it is usual to use a special kind of milk called by various trade names such as Creamo, Coffee Cream or Cereal Cream. What is the technical name for this special kind of milk?

text: The recipe for milk paint is a 1:1 ratio. First, measure and add water to a clean jar. Measure and add milk paint powder to the water. Mix thoroughly, using a whisk, for approximately three minutes or until smooth. Tips: Make sure it is mixed thoroughly before painting. It should have a table cream consistency for opaque coverage. Add more water if it is too thick or more powder if it is too thin.

text: All pasteurized whipping creams and most table creams with 15-per-cent butter fat contain carrageenan, but the thickening agent is rarely put in table cream with 10-per-cent butterfat (b.f.).
